author: Special Correspondent
text:
The Railway Mixed High School stepped into its centenary year on January 13, incidentally when it has switched over to CBSE (Central Board of Secondary Education) pattern.

Taking part in Trifest 2016, signifying the celebration of centenary year, annual and sports day and Pongal, Divisional Railway Manager of Salem Division Shubhranshu laid foundation stone for new buildings and centenary arch in the presence of Jyotsna Prasad, President, Southern Railway Women’s Welfare Organisation, Salem Division, and school correspondent and divisional personnel officer G. Janarthanan.

The DRM exuded hope that the school would sustain its top-notch academic performance under the new pattern.

Starting off with primary classes under Anglo-Indian syllabus, it was upgraded as high school in 1997. The school was affiliated to CBSE in the academic year 2015-16, in deference to requests from parents, for sustaining importance to sports, scouting, science fairs and cultural programmes and involving students in activities of various clubs: National Green Corps (NGC), Junior Red Cross (JRC), Literary Association, Karate, Yoga Club and Humour Club.

In the last couple of years, the school’s audio-visual room, library and play area were spruced up. The audio-visual room was named after late former President A.P.J. Abdul Kalam.

Railway employees

Patronage for the school has increased after its switchover to the new pattern. The decline in admissions in recent years was reversed; there have been 62 admissions this year, School Principal M. Dasan, said.

Of the 549 students, 246 are children of railway employees, he said.

title: Railway Mixed High School celebrates centenary year
